title: Ripple v. SEC: Top Lawyer Provides Insight into Potential End Date of May 6 - U.Today
content:
Pro-crypto lawyer and legal representative for XRP holders John Deaton has provided clarity regarding his statement about the possible end of the SEC's case against Ripple on May 6. According to Deaton, the suggestion is based on a previous case by the same judge, Analisa Torres, who then granted summary judgment 60 days after her Daubert decision.

Advertisement

This term in U.S. jurisprudence refers to a decision based on a legal ruling that sets standards for the admissibility of scientific and expert testimony in court. In the SEC's case against Ripple, the Daubert decision was to exclude the testimony of SEC witness Patrick Doody, hired by the regulator to analyze the motives of XRP buyers.

Nothing concrete

Given that the exclusion of Doody's evidence occurred on March 6, and previous experience with this judge suggests that another 60 days should elapse, one would expect the case to be resolved by May 6, says Deaton. However, the lawyer immediately stresses that he does not consider it an exact date, only that he would be surprised, but not shocked, if it did happen.

All in all, a potential end date of May 6, based on previous experience, may offer investors and enthusiasts some insight into when the SEC's case against Ripple will be resolved. As many had previously expected, including Ripple CEO, Brad Garlinghouse, things would be settled in the first half of 2023. However, as is often the case with any legal case, there is always the possibility of unexpected delays.

title: Brothers Cider unveils new Raspberry Ripple flavour - Grocery Trader
content:
Somerset-based Brothers Drinks Co., maker of the Brothers Cider brand renowned for its innovative fruit flavours, is to continue its tradition of introducing a weird and wonderful flavour to the category each year with the launch of Brothers Raspberry Ripple.

This latest variant is a delicious combination of raspberry flavour with a delicate swirl of vanilla, and is best served chilled over ice. Introducing this classic ice-cream flavour to the cider category will help independents tap into consumer excitement around summer socialising occasions.

Available in 500ml and 330ml glass bottles, and in 6x330ml and 10x330ml multipack can formats, Brothers Raspberry Ripple launches this spring, with RRPs aligned to existing variants. The highly innovative flavour will appeal for a diverse range of occasions in the run up to summer and beyond.

Brothers is the only brand in growth in the fruit cider category, with value +3.3% and volume +9.6%[1]; over the last year, the brand’s volume per trip has increased by an impressive 12.5%1.

The launch of Brothers Raspberry Ripple will be supported with a disruptive marketing campaign comprising influencer partnerships, social media activations, and POS materials available to drive visibility in depots and in-store.

Nicola Randall, head of marketing, Brothers Drinks Co., says: “Flavour innovation is what we do best at Brothers. We break the mould and bring all-new flavours to the cider category; we know our range of curious flavours has broad appeal across a wide range of consumers1. We’re adding to our successful range of highly original variants with Raspberry Ripple, which draws its inspiration from the world of ice-cream. The new flavour will hold strong appeal for impulse shoppers and comes hot on the heels of our already-popular Cherry Bakewell variant launched in 2022.”

www.brotherscider.co.uk

Sales enquiries: info@brothersdrinks.co.uk

[1] Source: 52 w/e Kantar purchase data until 7th August 2022

title: This is What’s Holding XRP’s Price Back According to Former Lawyer - CryptoPotato
content:
Scott Chamberlain – a former US lawyer and co-founder of EvernodeXRPL – thinks the main obstacle that stops XRP’s price from surging is the SEC’s claim that the token classifies as security.

On the other hand, Ripple – the entity which issues the coin – has maintained that XRP should be treated as a commodity.

In a recent Twitter post, Chamberlain opined that XRP’s price suppression is not caused by the US SEC’s allegation that Ripple sold assets worth more than $1 billion in 2013 but by the regulator’s “crucial distinction” that the token is a security.

I think a crucial distinction is SEC has alleged “XRP is a security” so the entire chain is threatened. If they only alleged Ripple sold XRP as part of an Investment Contract then there would be no threat, no price suppression – and no case because it would have settled long ago https://t.co/2bKVuuydiv — Scott Chamberlain (@scotty2ten) April 6, 2023

Prior to Chamberlain’s reaction on the social media platform, the financial expert Fredo Ayala said up to 5 million people depend on the lawsuit between Ripple and the SEC since they have invested in XRP and are expecting a possible price expansion.

The legal battle started in 2020 when the watchdog accused the blockchain organization of raising substantial funds through the sale of XRP tokens in an unregistered security offering to investors in 2013.

Ripple’s executives have repeatedly claimed over the years that coin should be viewed as a commodity. Chief Technology Officer David Schwartz recently explained why:

“XRP is a raw good that trades in commerce, and one XRP is treated as equivalent to every other XRP. That’s pretty much the definition of a “commodity.” No part of XRP’s value comes from anyone else’s legal obligations to XRP holders.”

For his part, Gary Gensler – Chairman of the SEC – said the only digital asset the agency is willing to classify only as a commodity is bitcoin.

Despite the uncertainty of the lawsuit’s outcome and the lengthy process, XRP’s valuation has recently headed north. It currently trades at approximately $0.51, or a 34% increase compared to the figures 30 days ago.
